awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Fabric Supercapacitor for Solar Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a special textile product capable of harvesting and storing solar energy. The potential application of the proposed technology is for alternative power supplies and battery devices. Current alternative power supplies are indispensable in remote rural areas where people lack access to reliable power grid infrastructure. However, travelers, hikers, or campers may find these alternatives cost- or safety-prohibitive. Disaster relief or military personnel deployed to remote areas may find that in addition to the mobility issues, current battery devices are costly on a large scale and fuel solutions are risky for those supplying fuel to those situated in hostile environments. Using the proposed technology, a hiker’s or soldier’s backpack may be turned into a power supply. A solar cell may be sewn into the bag to harvest solar energy that will be stored by the bag supercapacitor. Similarly, the fabric supercapacitor may be embedded into tent material, making the tent into a solar power supply as well. A sustainable, self-powered system make it possible for travelers to remote areas or for soldiers deployed for military operations. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a technology for making fabric supercapacitors (FSCs). The proposed technology includes various fabric materials, structural design of the fabric, and a novel fabrication approach. The energy storage ability of the FSC device will be determined by the size of the fabric areas used for forming the supercapacitor structure.  Compared with conventional supercapacitors, the proposed FSC technology is flexible, light weight, and safe. In addition, the bendable, twistable, rollable, and foldable design provides space that may be inaccessible to conventional supercapacitors. A demonstration of the technology showed that four series supercapacitors illuminated a red LED for more than 130 min and still maintained a voltage output around 1.61 V. The supercapacitor was susceptible to cyclic bending in 0-180 degree angles without losing its performance.  The proposed all-fabric FSC technology potentially may be adopted into many textile products acquiring the functions of solar energy harvesting and electric power storage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The University of Texas at Austin

por.por_cntn:
Transportable energy storage, in its many forms, typically embodies difficult tradeoffs: toxicity, weight, flexibility, material sourcing, sustainability, form factor, and safety. Textile based energy storage systems provide a viable solution to many of these issues. The technology advanced in this project is a supercapacitive fabric that can be used to make textile-based products, i.e. products which store energy within the fabric itself. This innovation has a broad impact on science and technology for new energy storage devices, as well as many potential end-uses. For example, the supercapacitive fabric may be coupled with flexible solar cells to create sustainable and transportable off-grid energy for use in clothing or in materials to create temporary shelters for housing and powering military, disaster relief victims, refugees, or other populations in remote or austere environments that may require power for communication, medical diagnostics, heating, and lighting.

This NSF I-Corps project included 7-weeks of intensive course study and training on customer discovery and business model development, customer interviews both during and after the course and a final report on our findings. This project not only allowed us to validate the value proposition of the patented technology of fabric supercapacitor fabrication, but also taught us the fundamentals of customer discovery and helped us probe various technical and commercial approaches for advancing the technology readiness level.

We interviewed 190 customers throughout this project, including remote interviews during the I-Corps intensive course on customer discovery and in-person interviews at four industrial trade shows specializing in outdoor equipment retailing, technical textile manufacturing, and wearable technology product integration and located in Georgia, Colorado and Arizona. The major research outcomes we obtained throughout this project duration could be summarized in two aspects: identification of a potential market for the technology penetration and understanding of customer requirements for fabric supercapacitors being adopted into various end-use products.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Jonathan Chen
